content: Thanks to everyone who responded to the recent Pay Equity Survey. The preliminary data from the survey,combined with data from the Massachusetts Teachers Association (MTA), indicate that the districts listed below currentlyhave pay equity (defined as nurses employed full-time by a school district having the same salary schedule as the teachersand other professional support personnel in that specific district).

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: Please review this list. If you think that any of thedata is incorrect or if you have additional districts to add, please contact Barbara Connolly at

html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: . We received some conflicting data. Pay equity committee members may be contacting you to verifyinformation. The data collection and analysis continue and complete results will be available later in the year.

content: We lost our case on the Appeals Court level. After the decision of the Superior Court I guess that was expected, but still very disappointing. There was no hearing and no opportunity for arguments. The Appeals Court just reviewed the case. Neil Rossman, our attorney, was very disappointed as well. He felt very strongly about our case and did an excellent job in presenting it, but the judges just did not seem to understand. This is the end of the line for this case; however, the Swampscott case is still alive.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: Even though we did not win in the courts, I think we should be proud of what we accomplished. We brought a lot of attention to the issue. When we began there were only 25 districts with equity and now there are nearly 90. And many of the districts without equity have made huge strides in their salary scales. I like to think that this progress is a direct result of our courage in initiating the lawsuit. There is still a long way to go and the quest for equity will not end with this. MSNO plans to continue to explore other avenues to achieve the pay equity goal.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: Thank you to Ann Borges, Roberta Cobbett, Janice DiFillipo, Ann Greenbaum, Kathy Larson, Maureen Saunders, Joan Scheid, and Lee Thurston for their courage in joining me and MSNO in this suit. Every school nurse in the state owes them a great deal. And thanks also to each of you who so generously gave your financial and emotional support to this venture. Please contact me if you have any questions or any new ideas. If you would like a copy of the Appeals Court decision, contact Barbara Connolly at her msno.org e-mail address.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td center b font span
html body text align table tbody tr td center b font span
html body text align table tbody tr td center b font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: The following list is an unofficial report on districts with pay equity for school nurses. Please notifyBarbara Connolly at her msno.org e-mail address of any additions orcorrections. We define "pay equity" to mean school nurses who are employed full-time by a school district have exactly the same salary schedule as the teachers and other professional support personnel (i.e. guidance counselors, librarians, adjustment counselors, speech therapists, etc.) in that specific district. This means that the school nurse can progress up all the steps (for seniority) and across all the columns (for education) that a teacher can.

content: On January 18, 2001, a hearing was held in Suffolk Superior Court on the Massachusetts Department of Education's Motion to Dismiss the suit filed by MSNO (Ann L. Greenbaum et. al. vs. Mass. Department of Education, et. al.) Unfortunately, Judge Thayer Freemont-Smith's opinion supported the Department of Education's Motion to Dismiss.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: We are now in the appeal process. Attorney Rossman filed an intent to appeal. The brief is due in mid-September. It is prepared and will be filed in a timely manner. We must now be patient again and wait for the next step in the legal process.

html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul font span
content: The following information summarizes the history leading up to this action:

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote span
content: The Massachusetts Education Reform Act of 1993 amended the teacher certification act to include school nurses. The position of "school nurse" in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is now defined by statute. Despite the fact that since June 1993 school nurse certification requirements are equal to, and in some areas even more rigorous than, those for teachers and other non-classroom based educational support personnel, most professional school nurses in Massachusetts are denied compensation equal to other professionals employed by the school system.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: It is MSNO's contention that the practice of salary inequities ultimately impacts the quality of health care delivered to students, since it is difficult to attract and retain school nurses with expertise in critical thinking, decision making, program management, health education and counseling, program planning, and community outreach, when competitive salaries are not offered.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: Groups of nurses in individual school systems have historically had little success in securing equitable contracts. Despite the current statewide and national recognition of the positive impact of school nurses on children's health, the expanded public health role of school nurses, and the need for their professional education, many of Massachusetts' school nurses report that they continue to feel undervalued, unempowered, and isolated. In spite of their many attempts to campaign for adequate compensation, comparable to other professionals in the school system, they have continuously been denied pay equity.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: Consequently in September 1997 the Massachusetts School Nurse Organization (MSNO) formed a "Pay Equity Committee" and began a statewide effort to address the problem of school nurse salary inequities.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: In January 1998 MSNO conducted a statewide survey that confirmed that only a small minority of the school districts in the Commonwealth pay school nurses on the same pay scale as their professional counterparts with equal educational and certification requirements. (The survey report, entitled

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p i span
content: Report on the Current State of Salary Inequities for Professional School Nurses in Massachusetts,

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: is available from MSNO.) The vast majority of school nurses in Massachusetts are significantly under-compensated.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: In November 1999 a complaint was filed in Essex County Superior Court. Plaintiffs were Ann Greenbaum, RN and Roberta Cobbett, RN, school nurses in the Swampscott Public Schools. Defendants were the Chairman of the Swampscott School Committee, the Superintendent of the Swampscott School Department and the duly elected Swampscott School Committee.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul blockquote p span
content: On July 25, 2000 a lawsuit was filed in Suffolk County Superior Court by Attorney Neil Rossman, Civil Action No. #00-3348-F.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center b font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: The Massachusetts Attorney General's office is representing the Department of Education in the matter of the Pay Equity lawsuit. The Assistant Attorney General for Administrative Law is filing a

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote b span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: and has submitted this motion to MSNO's attorney, Neil Rossman. Attorney Rossman will submit a response to this motion. It will be the

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote b span
content: "Opposition of Plaintiffs to Defendants' Motion to Dismiss."

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote b span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: and the response will then be filed with the court and will be reviewed by a judge. We will keep you updated on this website as the legal proceedings unfold.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: Newspapers across the state remain interested in doing articles on school nurses generally and on the pay equity issue in particular. Journalists are very willing to pay attention to nurses. A recently published book entitled

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p u span
content: From Silence to Voice: What Nurses Know and Must Communicate to the Public

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: by Bernice Buresh and Suzanne Gordon presents a practical guide that provides approaches to increase nurses' visibility and voice in the media. We have found during this campaign for pay equity that the media is very interested in our issues. Do not be intimidated. Contact your local newspapers and cable stations to publicize the pay equity issue. We need to be heard and each of you can make a difference in your area. Please feel free to contact Barbara Connolly at her msno.org e-mail address or

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p a span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p u i span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: ran an article entitled "School Nurses Keep Busy" in which they featured the nurses in the Freetown/Lakeville School District.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p u i span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: on Sunday October 8, 2000 carried a feature article entitled "School Nurses Demand More Pay." Nurses from Duxbury, Hanover and Freetown/Lakeville were spotlighted. On October 22, 2000

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p u i span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: published the following letter-to-the-editor, submitted by Barbara Connolly on behalf of MSNO, in response to comments made in the article by Hanover's superintendent of schools.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote u span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: stated that "the public wants a nurse to be a warm, caring human being. The intellectual acumen needed to practice professional nursing is rarely understood." This statement applies to school superintendents and school committees who rarely seem to recognize the role of school nurses and certainly do not seem to understand the "intellectual acumen" required of these nurses.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: The practice of professional nursing by school nurses occurs within the complex and unpredictable setting of the educational institution, not in a medical facility. A school nurse usually functions as a sole practitioner in her school.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p u span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: , published by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health in 1995, reminds us that the comprehensive and expanding public health nature of school nursing practice demands an educational and skill level that enables the school nurse to meet the current health needs of the students and staff. Why then, do the majority of school districts in the Commonwealth continue to devalue the nursing profession by refusing to pay nurses on the same salary scale as teachers

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p b span
content: and other non-classroom based educational support staff?

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: It is the Massachusetts School Nurse Organization's contention that the practice of salary inequities ultimately impacts the quality of health care delivered to students, since it is difficult to attract and retain school nurses with expertise in critical thinking, decision making, program management, health education and counseling, program planning, and community outreach, when competitive salaries are not offered.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center b font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center b span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul span
content: It appears that school districts which deny school nurses pay equity are violating the Education Reform Act's statement of nondiscrimination. A summary of the issues in the lawsuit are as follows:

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ol li span
content: under the Education Reform Act school nurses are required to be certified like all other educational professionals and to have a bachelor's degree as a prerequisite to certification...

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ol li span
content: school nurses are professional educators, as are all other non-classroom based educational support staff...

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ol li span
content: under Education Reform school nurses are the legal equal of other certified educators...

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ol li span
content: in spite of having to meet the same requirements as classroom teachers pay equity and professional standing are denied the school nurses...

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ol li span
content: salary schedules for school nurses are much lower than all other educational professionals...

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul span
content: Also, the Education Reform Act states (Section 99 of Statutes of 1993, Chapter 71):

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul ul span
content: "All programs and actions undertaken under the provisions of this act shall be conducted in a manner reflecting and encouraging a policy of nondiscrimination and equal opportunity for members of minority groups and women. All officials...of any school department...shall take affirmative steps to ensure equality of opportunity in the internal affairs of such departments...Each school district department...shall adopt measures to ensure equal opportunity in the areas of hiring, promotion,...rates of compensation and in-service training programs..."

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote ul p span
content: The MSNO Board of Directors has voted to support this legal action to achieve pay equity for school nurses. More information will be forthcoming to every school nurse in the State regarding how they can lend their encouragement and financial support to this undertaking.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center b font span
content: MSNO Advances with Pay Equity Legal Action

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: The MSNO Pay Equity Committee wishes to thank all who have contributed to the MSNO Legal Action Fund. In the short time since

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: we have informed our membership and other school nurse colleagues of our legal action process and our need for funding this action, we have raised $17,000. The requested amount to contribute is $50. Individual school nurses' contributions have ranged from $25 to $1,000. We thank you profoundly! Since we anticipate needing $50,000, we hope that those who have not yet contributed will do so soon.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote u span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: contribution is necessary if this legal action is to succeed.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: We have had a wonderful show of support from local unions, with donations ranging from $50 to $500! The MTA has been contacted by Linda Salmonsen, requesting that MTA contribute financially, as well as to encourage the support of the individual locals. NASN's Legal Defense Fund and the Connecticut Association of School Nurses have also been most generous in contributing to our legal action.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: With the filing of this legal suit, the MSNO Pay Equity Committee will post various sample letters that school nurses may use to request contributions from their local unions and/or friends of school nursing-either private individuals or organizations which have supported school nurses and school health services.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: We will keep you posted as this legal action progresses.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center b font span
html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: Several local unions have made generous contributions to the MSNO Legal Action Fund, such as Lanesborough, Dighton-Rehoboth, Brookline, Hanover, Westford and Central Berkshire. Ask your local if they have contributed. Show them the information on this website or in your newsletter which describes the Pay Equity lawsuit. Ask them to make a contribution to show their support financially. We are planning an "Honor Roll of Contributing Locals" to show our appreciation for their support for this legal action and for their school nurses.

tag: html body text align table tbody tr td blockquote center b font span
